generation project for meeting the country’s rapidly growing power 
demand.  A  least-cost  power  generation  option,  the  Project  is

expansion  of  Mong  Duong  thermal  power  complex  through  the 
construction  of  the  1,000–1,200  MW  Mong  Duong  2  thermal

also  provide  appropriate  institutional  and  technical  capacity 
building, particularly in CFB boiler technology and operation.   
 
Viet Nam’s economy has been growing at about 7.5% a year over 
the  past  decade,  with  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  in 
2006  reaching  8.2%.  The  Government  is  determined  to  maintain 
the  high  economic  growth  of  8%–8.5%  in  the  country’s  5-year 
socioeconomic  development  plan  (for  2006–2010)  to  reduce 
poverty to 11%–15% by 2010. To sustain this economic growth, a 
reliable supply of electricity is essential, as electricity is central to 
almost  every  aspect  of  Viet  Nam’s  sustainable  socioeconomic 
development:  job  creation,  industrial  activities,  commerce  and 
businesses,  and  other  drivers  of  economic  growth  and  people’s 
well-being.  Following  Viet  Nam’s  accession  to  the  World  Trade 
Organization  (WTO)  in  2007,  foreign  direct  investment  and 
domestic  investment  have  increased  substantially,  with  new 
businesses being established at an ever-increasing rate.

the country’s generation capacity, Viet Nam is experiencing power 
outages,  and  these  will  increase  unless  new  generation  capacity

The  high  growth  rate  in  electricity  demand,  coupled  with  the 
country’s  disproportionate  dependency  on  hydropower,  has  left 
Viet  Nam  with  dangerously  low  reserves  during  annual  dry 
seasons,  when  limited  river  flows  reduce  hydropower  output  to 
about  40%–50%  of  rated  output.  Without  significant  increases  in 
thermal  plant  generation  capacity,  the  continuing  demand  for 
electricity would reduce system reserve capacity to zero by 2010. 
Viet  Nam  Electricity  (EVN),  therefore,  plans  to  develop  thermal 
power plants urgently based on coal, including Mong Duong 1, to 
address system imbalances and seasonal generation shortages.  
 
The Government has made a policy decision to use domestic and 
imported  coal  to  ensure  security  of  electricity  supply.  Under  the 
updated  6th  Power  Development  Master  Plan,  coal  power  plants 
are  to  provide  for  essential  base-load  power  generation.  Coal’s 
share  in  the  country’s  generation  mix  will  more  than  double  from 
16% (in 2006) to 34% in 2020, while the share of hydropower will 
fall  gradually  from  37%  in  2006  to  27%  in  2020.  Nevertheless, 
hydropower  will  remain  the  second  largest  component  in  the 
generation  capacity  mix.  The  proposed  Project  is  in  Quang  Ninh 
Province  of  northern  Viet  Nam,  where  coal  is  abundant—
accounting for 90% of the country’s coal reserves. Viet Nam is a 
signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, though it is not required to reduce 
carbon emissions under the agreement, which lasts until 2012.  
 
The  2005  United  Nations  Framework  Convention  on  Climate 
Change  shows  that  Viet  Nam  emits  0.3  tons  of  carbon  dioxide 
(CO2) per capita, compared with 6.3 tons per capita by Japan, 8.8 
tons  per  capita  by  the United  Kingdom,  and  20.6  tons  per  capita 
by  the  United  States  of  America.  As  Viet  Nam’s  economy 
develops,  its  consumption  of  energy  will  increase  to  sustain  the 
economic growth and reduce poverty to 15%. In this context, Viet 
Nam is aware that the country’s CO2 emissions will increase, and 
is  using  clean  coal  technologies  in  power  generation  to  reduce 
CO2 emissions.

The Project will foster sustainable national economic growth, and 
generate employment. Expanding power generation capacity and 
providing  reliable  power  supplies  will  support  the  Government’s 
efforts to accelerate poverty reduction. Improving the reliability of 
the  power  supply  during  the  dry  season  will  ensure  a  stable 
supply  of  electricity  to  meet  the  growing  demand  of  industrial, 
commercial,  residential,  and  rural  consumers,  preventing  further 
load  shedding. 2  The  Project  will  also  address  the  current 
imbalance  between  hydropower  and  thermal  generation  capacity 
in the power system by increasing base-load thermal generation. 
Further, the Project will support private sector development in the 
power  sector.  By  financing  the  required  common  facilities  for 
Mong Duong 2, the Project permits EVN to award that project on a 
stand-alone basis for private sector participatory development.

The  Government  selected  two  loans  under  the  MFF  as  its 
preferred mode of financing for the Project, rather than adopting a 
traditional project loan, largely due to (i) the loan being almost $1 
billion,  when  only  about  $27.86  million  is  needed  in  the  first  2 
years; (ii) the need for sufficient time to design, bid, negotiate, and 
award  the  main  engineering,  procurement,  and  construction 
(EPC)  contract  to  a  suitable  contractor  (to  be  selected  under 
international  competitive  bidding,  following  ADB  guidelines);  and 
(iii)  apprehension  that  bids  for  the  EPC  contract  could  escalate 
unless the bidding community sees that financing is firmly in place

The  construction  of  the  1,000  MW  Mong  Duong  1  power  plant, 
together with site preparation and the common facilities for Mong 
Duong 2, will provide reliable electricity supply throughout the year 
in northern Viet Nam. The main beneficiaries of the Project will be 
the  industrial,  commercial,  residential,  and  rural  consumers  in 
northern  Viet  Nam.

fluctuations,  resulting  in  better  performance  and  longer  life  of 
electrical equipment. EVN will not have to resort to load shedding, 
which will support the development of the northeast region, where 
numerous industrial estates are established. The stable supply of 
electricity  to  northern  Viet  Nam  will  stimulate  economic  growth, 
and  increase  employment  and  income-earning  opportunities  for 
the  poor.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  the 
Project is estimated at 22.5%. The financial internal rate of return 
(FIRR)  is  estimated  at  7.5%,  which  is  higher  that  the  2.97%  real 
weighted  average  cost  of  capital.  The  Project  will  also  generate 
direct employment in the project area through construction of the 
Mong  Duong  power  complex,  incremental  coal  mining,  and 
limestone mining activities. 
 
The  Project  is  not  expected  to  be  subject  to  any  significant 
technical  risks.  EVN  has  proven  experience,  and  has  performed 
well  in  implementing  internationally  financed  power  projects. 
Capacity  building  of  EVN  technical  staff  under  the  Project  will 
improve  operational  knowledge  and  skills  regarding  CFB  boiler 
technology. The financial and economic robustness of the Project 
has  been  evaluated,  taking  into  consideration  possible  variations 
of  key  parameters.  The  main  factors  that  might  pose  risks to  the 
financial and economic viability of the Project are (i) lower demand

2. 
Viet  Nam’s  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  has  grown  on  average  about  7.5%  a  year

sectors  of  the  economy.  The  CSP  highlights  the  importance  of  removing  infrastructure

10. 
ADB’s approach has been to provide financial and institutional support for power sector 
development  to  help  the  Government  achieve  its  development  objectives.  ADB’s  development 
assistance strategy has focused on (i) expanding and strengthening the country’s high-voltage 
transmission  backbone  network;  (ii)  developing  least-cost  generation  projects  (hydro  and 
thermal)  to  meet  growing  power  demand;  (iii)  promoting  financial  and  fiscal  sustainability  by 
unbundling EVN into generation, transmission, and distribution companies that can operate as 
commercially  viable  and  financially  independent  entities;  (iv) creating  an  enabling  environment 
for  private  sector  participation  in  a  competitive  power  market  in  Viet  Nam;  (v) promoting 
renewable  energy  sources  for  power  generation  in  rural  areas;  and  (vi) promoting  power 
interconnections in the Greater Mekong Subregion to allow power trading within the region by 
using the difference in peak load demand, and taking advantage of the spare capacities within 
high-voltage power transmission networks. Within ADB, the public sector and private sector staff 
have cooperated closely to support the development of public-private partnerships in the power 
sector,  such  as  promoting  the  partnership  to  develop  Mong  Duong  1  and  2  projects  jointly.11 
Further, ADB has engaged the Government in policy dialogue to improve sector performance. 
As  a  result,  the  Government  has  agreed  with  ADB  on  the  road  map  for  the  sector 
(Supplementary Appendix A), which includes Mong Duong 1 and 2.

The  Project  is  included  in  the  Government's  5th  and  6th  PDMP.  The  long-term  system

A. 

Economic Analysis 

60. 
The economic viability of the Project was examined based on incremental costs incurred 
and  benefits  accrued  to  the  society.  This  analysis  was  conducted  by  comparing  the  societal 
costs and benefits of the "with Project" scenario against the "without Project" scenario. All costs 
and benefits were evaluated based on a domestic price numeraire. EVN estimated the Project's 
costs, which ADB staff checked and verified. Staff made adjustments to bring these estimated 
costs to include social costs by applying shadow exchange rate factor (SERF).26 
 
The costs to the society are the investment and operating costs of the Project, as well as 
61. 
the environmental mitigating costs. Investment costs, in turn, consist of (i) equipment costs; (ii) 
construction costs; and (iii) engineering, administrative, and management costs of power plant 
construction.  Fuel  (coal  and  limestone)  and  related  costs  account  for  a  significant  part  of  the 
operating  costs.  While  the  total  cost  takes  into  account  physical  contingencies,  it  excludes 
interest during the construction and price contingencies.  
 
62. 
The  economic  value  of  electricity  generated  by  the  Project  is  measured  by  using  the 
costs  to  the  society  of  not  having  the  Project  (the  so-called  avoided  costs).  These  costs 
comprise  the  costs  of  suboptimal  operation  of  thermal  power  plants  to  partially  offset  the 
shortage  of  electricity  resulting  from  not  having  the  Project,  and  the  costs  to  consumers 
(industrial, residential, commercial, and rural) due to no electricity. In other words, the societal 
benefits  of  the  Project  is  the  sum  of  two  components:  the  non-incremental  benefits  accrued 
through  savings  by  not  having  to  run  other  thermal  power  plants  suboptimally;  and  the 
incremental benefits accrued to the consumers by having sufficient supply of electricity to meet 
their needs, thus avoiding load shedding27 and associated economic losses.

constructed. The analysis also confirms that the Project, which is scheduled to be added to the

An  additional  analysis  was  carried  out  to  examine  the  possible  impacts  of  a  large 
investment  such  as  this  Project  on  the  country’s  debt  sustainability  and  other  macroeconomic 
indicators. The analysis was based on an ADB OCR assessment paper, draft 2007–2010 CSP, 
and  the  calculation  of  foreign  exchange  flow  of  the  Project.  This  analysis  showed  that  the 
project  investment  does  not  alter  the  debt  sustainability  of  the  country  in  the  medium  to  long 
term, because the disbursement of the loan is within the OCR limit. Since more than 70% of the 
ADB loan will be awarded under an EPC contract, the Project will not have significant effects on 
supply or consumer sectors, and does not suggest excessive inflation. Further, the Project will 
generate sufficient revenue to repay its associated loans. The financial evaluation of the Project 
was  undertaken  in  real  terms  using  constant  2006  prices.  The  project  cost  estimates  and 
financial  projections  in  nominal  terms  were  converted  to  real  terms  by  adjusting  the  projected 
effects of foreign and domestic inflation, and currency fluctuations. The energy generated by the 
Project was conservatively valued at $0.041 per kWh, based on the price paid by EVN to IPPs. 
The  cost  estimates  in  Appendix  5  are  used  for  the  financial  analysis,  excluding  price 
contingencies  and  interest  during  construction.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR), 
computed after tax, is 6.59%. This compares favorably with the weighted average cost of capital 
(WACC),  also  computed  after  tax,  of  2.85%.  The  Project  is  considered  financially  viable  and 
sustainable.  Sensitivity  analysis  indicates  the  FIRR  remains  robust  under  adverse  conditions. 
The detailed financial analysis is in Appendix 11.

FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE AND PROJECTIONS OF VIET NAM ELECTRICITY  

General Overview 

 
A. 
 
Vietnam  Electricity  (EVN)  is  a  large  and  complex  organization  whose  core  business  is 
1. 
the  supply  of  electricity  throughout  Viet  Nam.  However,  EVN  also  has  some  non-core 
businesses  engaged  in  manufacturing  and  other  industries,  the  largest  being  EVN  Telecoms. 
EVN  is  organized  into  a  number  of  different  types  of  entities,  including  15  independent 
accounting  units,  20  dependent  accounting  units,  6  administrative  units,  14  construction  and 
project  management  units,  and  some  subsidiaries  and  joint  ventures  in  which  EVN  controls 
more than 50% of the voting rights. In early 2007, the Government decided to convert EVN into 
a  holding  company  called  Viet  Nam  Electricity  (EVN)  and  most  of  its  operating  entities  will  be 
converted to limited liability companies with EVN retaining whole or partial ownership. 

2. 
EVN  was created in 1995 as a vertically integrated entity responsible for the electricity 
sector  in  Viet  Nam.  EVN’s  operations  have  been  profitable  and  it  has  financed  the  rapid 
expansion  of  the  electricity  sector  without  significant  fiscal  subsidies.  The  key  financial 
performance indicators, such as debt service coverage ratio (DSCR), self-financing ratio (SFR), 
and  receivables,  have  been  maintained  at  prudential  limits.  Meanwhile,  the  average  end  user 
tariff  has  been  maintained  at  around  Vietnamese  Dong  (D)  853  per  kilowatt-hour  (kWh) 
($0.053/kWh).  However,  to  satisfy  future  demand  for  electricity  resulting  from  rapid  economic 
growth,  EVN  will  need  to  make  considerable  investments  in  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution. A substantial portion of these investments will be financed by debt, sustained tariff 
increases  are  required  to  maintain  adequate  levels  of  debt  service  and  self  financing  of  these 
new investments. 

B. 

Historical Performance 

3. 
EVN's electricity sales have doubled in 2000–2005, representing average annual growth 
of  15.2%.  Although  the  average  tariffs  net  of  sales  taxes  have  increased  only  marginally  from 
D660/kWh  ($0.047/kWh)  in  2000  to  D810/kWh  ($0.05/kWh)  by  2005,  EVN’s  revenue  has 
increased  from  D16.8  trillion  ($1,160  million)  in  2000  to  D38.0  trillion  ($2,400  million)  in  2005. 
Further, its net profit nearly tripled from D888 billion ($62 million) in 2000 to D2.8 trillion (about 
$180 million) in 2005.  

4. 
In  recent  loans  approved  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  World  Bank,  the 
Banks  and  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  (the  Government)  agreed  to  adopt  new  financial 
covenants  based  on  (i)  consolidated  EVN  financial  statements;  and  (ii)  EVN's  overall  financial 
viability  and  performance,  rather  than  arbitrarily  setting  tariffs  in  foreign  currency.  These 
covenants  were  included  in  two  recently  approved  loans 1 as  follows:  (i)  self-financing  ratio 
(SFR) of 25%, (ii) debt service coverage ratio (DSCR) of 1.5, and (iii) debt-equity ratio of 70:30. 
EVN complied with these covenants during 2000 to  2005. However, there has been a reduction 
in EVN’s net cash flow and operating profits due to absence of tariff increases from 2003 -2006. 
This has reduced the SFR to 25% in 2005 from 70% in 2003, and DSCR to 2.0 in 2005 from 5.3 
in 2003. This is expected to be reversed with tariff increases of 8.8% effective from 1 January 
2007 and a further 5% increase in July 2008. The retail tariffs beyond 2009 will be adjusted to 
reflect the market prices in the competitive generation market to be set up in 2009.

Sales and Income 

5. 
The  fastest  growth  in  electricity  sales  has  been  in  the  industrial  sector,  where  the 
average annual growth was between 17% and 18% during 2000-2005 period. As a result, the 
industrial  sector’s  share  of  overall  demand  increased  from  40%  in  2000  to  45%  in  2005.  The 
household sector also has shown considerable annual growth, averaging 12% over the past 12 
years. This is a result of increasing demand by existing customers and additional demand from 
new connections, as more households are connected to the electricity supply system.  

More than 90% of EVN’s revenue comes from electricity sales, with only 8% from other 
6. 
services and products. Income from the telecommunications business, at D378 billion in 2005,is  
less than 1% of EVN’s total income. However, EVN Telecoms has its own ambitious investment 
and expansion plans, particularly regarding the development of its mobile telephone service and 
is expected to be a major contributor to EVN’s consolidated revenues from 2007 onwards. 

2.  

Production and Supply 

7. 
In  2005,  EVN  produced  more  than  52.3  terawatt-hours  (TWh)  from  its  own  power 
stations, and purchased an additional 12.5 TWh from independent power producers (IPP). The 
largest  source  of  power  was  hydroelectricity  (33%),  followed  by  gas  turbines  (28%),  fuel  oil 
(23%),  and  coal-fired  power  stations  (16%).  IPPs  (including  imports)  account  for  24%  of  total 
supply. However, electricity from hydropower has declined by 7% due to adverse hydrological 
conditions, resulting in a deficit that has been made up primarily from gas-fired power stations 
and an increase in power purchases from IPPs. As the gas-fired power plants are in the south, 
power is transmitted to the north at a high cost to meet the power shortages. This has resulted n 
higher operating expenses and lower operating profits in 2005 compared to 2004.  

3. 

Operating Costs 

8. 
Depreciation is one of the largest operating costs for EVN, accounting for over 30% of its 
operating  costs.  Under  the  Vietnamese  Accounting  System  (VAS),  depreciation  periods  are 
generally shorter than those allowed under International Accounting Standards, which accounts 
for the relatively high levels of depreciation. EVN also relies on these high levels of depreciation 
to  fund  its  future  capital  expenditure  program  and  to  improve  the  SFR.  The  other  major  cost 
items are fuel costs for thermal power stations and purchased electricity from IPPs. EVN uses 
lower calorific value (4,000–5,500 kilocalories per kilogram [kcal/kg] of domestic anthracite coal 
for power generation. Generally, this coal has little value unless it is washed. The higher-quality 
anthracite coal is exported as coking coal. For this type of coal, EVN’s cost currently varies from 
$24–$28/ton but future prices will increase. Gas prices are denominated in US dollars, based on 
agreed volume and long-term contracts. In recent months, new agreements have been linked to 
a  fuel  price  index  due  to  increased  drilling  costs.  EVN  does  not  receive  any  direct  operating 
subsidies  from  the  Government  to  cover  its  operating  costs.  However,  the  Government  does 
inject  additional  capital  to  help  finance  specific  investments,  such  as  the  Son  La  hydropower 
plant and provides access to lower interest loans from state-owned banks.  

4. 

Capital Expenditure 

During  2000–2005,  EVN  invested  more  than  D81.5 trillion  in  new  capital  works. 
9. 
Approximately  45%  of  this  expenditure  has  been  financed  by  taking  out  additional  long-term 
loans, while the remainder was financed from its own resources (50%) and capital injections by 
the Government (5%). Outstanding long-term loans have increased from about D26.9 trillion in 
2000 to more than D53.7 trillion by 2005.

2. 

Operating Expenses 

11. 
The  operating  expenses  of  EVN  largely  depend  on  the  plant  mix  used  for  meeting  the 
forecast  demand  and  fuel  price  projections.  The  plant  mix  for  2006–2011  is  based  on  the 
economic  merit  order  dispatch  of  the  available  plants  at  different  years,  subject  to  the

EVN  is  expected  to  increase  its  purchases  from  third  parties  from  12.5  TWh  in  2005  to  33.6 
TWh  from  by  2011—i.e.,  about  27%  of  total  generation  of  125 TWh  from  private  power 
producers, joint venture companies, and imports.  

12. 
Fuel  consumption  is  based  on  the  projected  plant  mix,  and  the  fuel  expenses  were 
based on Viet Nam’s expected domestic fuel prices. Coal prices are kept at around $24–$28 per 
ton  during  2005–2010.  Although  these  are  below  the  prevailing  international  coal  prices,  the 
coal  used  by  EVN  is  of  lower  quality.  As  such,  the  price  is  not  directly  comparable  with  the 
international  prices  for  good-quality  coal.  The  absence  of  data  on  actual  production  costs  of 
different  types  of  coal  mines  and  a  transparent  coal  market  in  Viet  Nam  make  identifying  any 
implicit subsidy to EVN through the discounted coal prices difficult. Gas prices are based on the 
production share agreements signed with the international gas field developers.  

3.  

Capital Expenditures 

13. 
EVN  is  to  make  cumulative  capital  investments  of  D234  trillion  ($14.2  billion)  during 
2006–2011, compared with D81.5 trillion during 2000–2005 implying a threefold increase in the 
capital  investment.  The  debt  service  commitment  during  2006–2011  will  also  increase  to  D79 
trillion,  compared  with  D20  trillion  in  the  previous  6-year  period.  In  addition  to  the  direct 
investments,  EVN  is  also  planning  to  form  joint  venture  companies  to  implement  some  of  the 
power generation projects (e.g., Hai Phong coal power plant) in 2006–2011, and plans to invest

including  the  private  sector  (mainly  in  power  generation),  would  complement  EVN’s  direct 
investments and investments through joint ventures.  

14. 
Although  its  internal  cash  generation  is  projected  to  reach  D152  trillion  ($9.5  billion) 
during  2006–2011,  EVN  will  finance  a  significant  portion  of  the  investments  through  net 
borrowings  totaling  D160  trillion.  This  represents  significantly  more  borrowing  compared  with

injections,  this  investment  plan  will  substantially  increase  EVN’s  debt  and  its  debt  service

Future Developments 

EVN  is  moving  away  from  its  traditional  role  of  generating  its  own  electricity  to  one  in

which  it  buys  a  considerable  amount  of  electricity  from  third  parties,  and  then  transmits  and 
distributes it to end users. There is a strong case for splitting EVN into a number of independent 
entities,  such  as  transmission  companies,  distribution  companies,  and  power  stations  (where 
the  State’s  shares  in  these  entities  are  held  by  a  Holding  Company),  as  a  way  of  increasing 
transparency in the functioning of the market. The Government has approved a plan for EVN to 
equitize  (i.e.,  partially  privatize)  minority  stakes  in  most  power  generation  plants  and  regional 
power companies. As of July 2007, three power plants, including a 1,000 MW coal power plant,

par  value  was  computed  net  of  the  liabilities.  The  cash  proceeds  from  the  equalization  will 
improve EVN’s cash flow. However, the debt-equity ratio of EVN as a consolidated entity will not 
be affected, as EVN intends to retain a majority stake in the equalized entities.  

16. 
As  a  means  of  attracting  non-EVN  investments  to  the  sector,  EVN  is  planning  to  form 
several joint ventures for the construction and operation of some power stations. The liabilities 
of new power plants to be developed as joint ventures between EVN and other parties—where 
EVN is expected to be the majority shareholder—are consolidated in the financial projections. In 
the case of joint ventures where EVN is the minority shareholder, EVN’s share of the expected 
profit  from  these  entities  appears  on  its  balance  sheet  as  profit  from  other  activities  in  the 
projections.

Proposed Covenants 

17.  With  EVN’s  increasing  indebtedness,  a  maximum  long-term  debt-equity  ratio  of  70:30

debt level and its debt service capacity remain within prudential limits. Although the debt-equity 
ratio is increasing steadily and DCSR is decreasing, they remain within these limits during the 
forecast period, except in 2010 when the debt-equity ratio exceeds 70:30. A minimum SFR of 
25%  is  imposed  to  ensure  that  EVN  generates  adequate  cash  flows  to  finance  a  reasonable

loan covenants in 2006 and future years depends largely on future tariff increases and fuel price

construction  in  progress  as  of  31  December  2000.  This  led  to  a  restatement  of  financial 
statements for 2000. In 2002, EVN revalued some of its power station assets, which increased 
their value by about D3,000 billion. The external auditors noted that this revaluation violated IAS 
principles,  because  any  revaluation  should  be  applied  to  the  whole  class  of  assets,  not  just  a 
subset.  Otherwise,  the auditors  have  not  made  any  significant  qualification  to  EVN’s  accounts 
during  the  past  5  years.  According  to  the  external  auditors,  EVN  and  all  of  its  units  generally 
keep  their  accounts  properly,  consistent  with  Viet  Nam’s  laws  and  regulations.  Further,  the 
auditors  commented  that  the  units  of  EVN  have  improved  how  quickly  they  produce  their 
accounts  over  the  last  few  years.  In  addition,  the  auditors  reported  that  fewer  management 
letters  have  noted  improved  procedures  in  recent  years  with  fewer  significant  internal  control 
issues identified, while the number of qualified audit opinions has declined.  
 
14. 
In  March  1998,  EVN  established  its  Internal  Audit  Department,  which  is  headed  by  a 
chief  of  internal  audit  and  supported  by  five  professional  accountants.  EVN  relies  heavily  on 
direct  supervision,  detailed  reporting,  and  authorization  from  top  management  for  internal 
control.  This  internal  audit  ensures  proper  checks  and  balances,  and  delineation  of 
responsibilities. Internal reviews are conducted as follows: (i) the Inspection Department, with a 
team  of  selected  representatives  from  the  various  business  units,  conducts  inspections  on 
compliance with EVN policies and Government rules and regulations; (ii) an ad hoc inspection 
team  selected  by  the  director  general  conducts  inspections  for  certain  activities  of  business 
units;  (iii)  the  Finance  and  Accounting  Department  team  handles  accounting  supervision;  and 
(iv)  the  Management  Board  and  the  Control  Section  of  the  Board  carry  out  inspections. 
Inspections are conducted based on Government guidelines, and focus on the reviews of plans, 
expenditures,  contracts,  and  compliance.  TPPMU1  has  not  been  subject  to  an  internal  audit 
report. 
 
15. 
The  consolidated  financial  accounts  of  EVN  are  submitted  to  the  Ministry  of  Industry, 
MOF,  and  Tax  Department  for  review  and  approval.  MOF  audits  are  used  to  determine  tax 
liabilities,  scheduled  payments  of  “state-rented”  capital,  and  other  financial  matters.  MOF’s 
revision committee has the right to audit any part of EVN, though TPPMU1 has not been subject 
to such an audit. EVN prepared financial statements of its previous projects in accordance with 
VAS.  The  TPPMU1  system  prepares  simple  financial  statements  monthly,  and  this  reporting 
should  be  adopted  to  report  on  this  Project.  Although  trying  to  link  physical  progress  with 
financial progress could be useful in predicting estimated completion date and total cost, this is 
not  really  necessary.  Most  contracts  by  TPPMU1  are  fixed-cost  contracts,  which  pay  a 
contractor a predetermined amount when it completes a specific amount of physical work.

hydropower,  coal,  natural  gas  and  oil,  and  some  potential  of  renewable  energy  sources.  The

into account the environment and social criteria, the feasible hydropower potential is estimated 
to be 20,750 MW, or 83 TWh per year’s production.

3. 

System Planning Methodology 

7. 
System  planning  is  formulated  based  on  the  set  of  candidate  plants,  taking  into 
consideration  constraints  that  reflect  the  fuel  availability  and  system  reliability  criteria  (power 
plant outage, maintenance requirement, transmission line reliability rule, etc.). Two gas supply 
possibilities were considered: 14 billion cubic meters and 10 billion cubic meters per year during 
2020–2025. The two most important reliability criteria are (i) the loss of load expectation (LOLE) 
criteria applied to the whole generation system, and (ii) the rule n-1 applied to the transmission 
capability.  The  LOLE  criterion  stipulates  that  the  expected  loss  of  load  should  not  exceed  24 
hours per year, expressed in hours LOLE < 24 per year. The n-1 rule takes care of the situation 
when one circuit of the double-circuit 500 kV line is not functioning, while the remaining system 
will still work stably. 
 
8. 
System  optimization  was  carried  out  using  software  based  on  dynamic  programming 
optimization  to  find  out  the  expansion  plan  with  lowest  total  discounted  costs.  Apart  from 
demand  data,  other  important  inputs  for  optimization  are  (i)  technical  and  financial  economic 
data  of  all  generation  sources,  fuel  types,  fuel  price,  investment  cost,  operation  and 
maintenance  (O&M)  cost,  efficiency,  load  factor,  failure  frequences,  etc.;  (ii)  investment  cost, 
voltage,  length,  O&M  cost,  losses, failure  frequences,  etc.,  for  transmission  lines; and  (iii)  fuel 
supply availability or limitation, and fuel costs. Investment costs of generation and transmission 
candidates are taken from prefeasibility studies, if available, or estimated based on international 
and  national  experiences.  Fuel  costs  are  forecasted  taking  into  account  international 
projections.  O&M  costs  are  based  on  the  domestic  and  international  practices.  The  costs  are 
economic costs without provision for taxes. Environmental costs are not included.

Sensitivity Analysis 

The  sensitivity  of  the  NPV  and  EIRR  to  the  main  input  parameters  has  been  analyzed

industrial,  and  commercial  consumers  attach  to  the  unserved  electricity.  Among  these  factors, 
total project cost plays an important role in the possible variation of cost components. As such, 
its  influence  on  the  total  cost  was  analyzed  first.  The  total  project  cost  was  broken  down  into 
equipment cost (54.2%), labor cost (16.5%), and cost of materials for construction (13.7%). The 
balance  is  made  up  by  contingencies,  and  environmental  and  social  costs.  According  to  the 
Ministry of Planning and Investment,5 the consumer price index (CPI) in Viet Nam increased an 
average  of  4.7%  per  year  during  2000–2005.  The  price  of  construction  materials  increased 
more  quickly  than  other  commodities.  While  energy  prices,  including  coal,  oil  products,  and 
electricity, are still regulated by the Government, they have increased slightly. Labor cost in Viet 
Nam is low and has not increased much.

industries,  rather  than  agriculture.  Tree  plantation  for  timber,  aquaculture,  and  fisheries  are  the  main  sources  of 
income at the commune level.  
 
The main project impacts are loss of jobs; land acquisition (refer to resettlement plan); and loss of forest, mangrove, 
and aquatic resources (refer to the environmental impact assessment). The Project will acquire forest plantation land 
from forest plantation cooperatives. Large land owners own the cooperatives, which have permanent wage  workers. 
Similarly, land from a big aquaculture pond will be acquired. The Mong Duong power plant will negatively impact the 
water quality and biological resources of marine coastal environment. The diversion of Mong Duong River and cooling 
water  discharge  channel  to  Cam  Hai  commune  would  have  adverse  affect  on  fishery  and  mangroves  (refer  to  EIA). 
The  resettlement  plan,  gender  strategy,  and  environment  management  plan  of  the  Project  include  strategies  to 
address these impacts on the local environment and livelihood of the people. 
 
Health. Coal mining in Cam Pha Town has been polluting the air and environment through discharge of wastewater, 
dust etc. The widespread diseases in the project area related to pollution are (i) respiratory problems, (ii) lung disease, 
and  (iii)  eyes  and  nose  infection.  In  Mong  Duong,  68%  of  children  suffer  from  respiratory  diseases,  and  50%  suffer 
from nose and eyes infections. These diseases are linked mainly to the coal dust generated by coal transportation. A 
substantial proportion of the coal mine workers have contracted silicosis. VINACOAL has a program to give its most 
severely  affected  workers  access  to  silicosis  treatment.  Coal  dust-related  health  problems  of  local  people  might 
increase  because  of  additional  dust  generated  by  the  Project.  During  project  implementation,  occupational  health 
measures will be developed to minimize health problems related to coal dust pollution for the workers.

implementing HIV/AIDS and human trafficking-related programs. From January 1999 to February 2003, Quang Ninh

Migration,  in  partnership  with  the  Women’s  Union,  implemented  an  18-month  Counter  Trafficking  Project  in  Quang 
Ninh Province, Viet Nam. A national program on AIDS is implemented in the province. In addition, several NGOs are 
present in Cam Pha, and have programs to prevent the spread of HIV/AIDS.  
 
Under the proposed Project, HIV/AIDs and human trafficking awareness program will be undertaken during pre- and 
post-construction phases in the project  area. The experience and  lessons from the  existing  program  in the  province

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
In  the  project  area,  the  main  economic  activities  include  forest  plantation,  fishery,  and  industry.  Gender  analyses 
include households affected by land acquisition and loss of fisheries. Women work in aquaculture and forest plantation 
as  wage  workers.  In  marine  fishery,  women  accompany  men  out  to  sea,  and  they  play  significant  role  in  all  fishing 
activities: catching fish, preparing nets, harvesting, cleaning, and selling fish. Women also are involved in white worm 
collection in the coastal area. Women in the forest plantation are involved in planting, taking care of trees, and cutting 
trees. In aquaculture, women are responsible for feeding fish and taking care of the pond. To ensure the participation 
women  in  project  activities  during  implementation  of  the  resettlement  plan,  as  well  as  HIV/AIDS,  human  trafficking, 
and health-related programs, the following measures are included in the gender strategy: 

At  project  inception,  a  capacity  building  training  program  on  resettlement  activities  will  be  designed  for 
women  and  men  commune  officials,  and  women  and  men  from  affected  households.  The  training  will 
also include representatives from line agencies, and representatives from the commune Women’s Union 
and  Youth  Union  involved  in  resettlement  committees.  The  training  will  include  information  on 
resettlement activities, compensation, and the impact of the Project on livelihood activities related to the 
loss  of  jobs  and  fisheries.  The  objective  of  the  training  is  to  provide  affected  communities  with  an 
understanding resettlement issues and the environmental impact of the Project on fisheries, mangroves, 
and health. The training  will facilitate effective implementation of the resettlement plan, and  will help in 
addressing of environment-related impacts on livelihoods.
